questions.text: A 49-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of a 5-month history of painful sexual intercourse. She also reports vaginal pruritus and occasional spotting. She has no pain with urination. She had two urinary tract infections over the past 3 years that resolved with oral antibiotic therapy. She has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypercholesterolemia. Her last menstrual period was 8 months ago. She is sexually active with her husband and has two children. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 29 years. Current medications include ramipril, metformin, atorvastatin, and aspirin. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 140/82 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows decreasing labial fat pad, receding pubic hair, and clear vaginal discharge. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fluconazole is an antifungal drug recommended for the treatment of vulvovaginal candidiasis. Although this infection may manifest with pruritus and an odorless vaginal discharge, the discharge is usually white and curd-like (“cottage cheese” appearance). Moreover, vulvovaginal candidiasis would also cause dysuria.

B) INCORRECT:

Nystatin is a second-line antifungal drug recommended for the treatment of vulvovaginal candidiasis. Although this infection may manifest with pruritus and an odorless vaginal discharge, the discharge is usually white and curd-like (“cottage cheese” appearance). Moreover, vulvovaginal candidiasis would also cause dysuria.

C) CORRECT:

Topical estrogen creams effectively alleviate symptoms of genitourinary syndrome of menopause, which is thought to be caused by low estrogen levels after menopause. Similar symptoms can also occur postpartum or during breastfeeding due to estrogen deficiency. Moisturizers and vaginal lubricants are an alternative for mild cases and can also be used as an adjunct to hormone treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Metronidazole is recommended as the first-line treatment for Gardnerella vaginalis and Trichomonas vaginalis infections. Although both infections may manifest with vaginal discharge, the discharge is usually foul-smelling and not clear. These infections would also not explain a decreasing labial fat pad or receding pubic hair.

E) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids are used for the treatment of lichen planus. Although genital lichen planus may also cause dyspareunia and mostly affects women over 50 years of age, it is frequently accompanied by several symptoms such as vulvar pain, pruritus, and burning. Moreover, it is commonly associated with cutaneous or oral lichen planus.
questions.hint: Receding pubic hair and decreasing labial fat pads are typical symptoms for genitourinary syndrome of menopause (atrophic vaginitis).

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of vulvar itching and dryness. During this period, she has also had pain during sexual intercourse but no postcoital bleeding. Her last menstrual period was at the age of 51 years. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and her only medication is metformin. Pelvic examination shows atrophic labial folds. There are excoriation marks and a well-demarcated, white plaque on the vulva. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The results of a punch biopsy show no evidence of malignancy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment for this patient's lesions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical fluconazole is indicated to treat mucocutaneous fungal infections like candidiasis (vaginal yeast infection). This patient's age puts her at increased risk of secondary infections of the genital area as a complication of atrophic vaginitis. A yeast infection would also explain the vulval pruritus and dyspareunia in this case. However, the absence of key features like vaginal discharge, foul odor, and vulvovaginal inflammation make this diagnosis unlikely.

B) CORRECT:

Individuals with lichen sclerosus have an increased risk of developing vulvar squamous cell carcinoma. Because the results of this patient's biopsy are negative for malignancy, the next step in management is to administer superpotent topical glucocorticoids, such as betamethasone or clobetasol, which help reduce inflammation and pruritus.
Image Description:

An irregular, sclerotic white plaque with a reddened, inflammatory edge localized to the vulva and perianal region is visible. The labia minora and majora are hard to distinguish from one another because of atrophy and sclerosis; the vaginal opening is markedly narrowed.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical tacrolimus (FK506) is a calcineurin inhibitor that can be used to treat lichen sclerosus topically. However, this is a second-line therapy because it is less effective than another therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Although topical progesterone was used in the past for lichen sclerosus, it is no longer used as it is less effective than other forms of therapy and is not approved by the FDA.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical estrogen is the treatment of choice for atrophic vaginitis, which often manifests in postmenopausal women with vulval dryness and dyspareunia in association with labial atrophy. However, this condition does not cause white, plaque-like lesions or pruritus.

F) INCORRECT:

Although UVA1 phototherapy has been shown to improve symptoms for lichen sclerosus, it is less effective than another form of therapy.
questions.hint: Dyspareunia and pruritus in a postmenopausal woman with a white vulvar plaque on pelvic examination are consistent with lichen sclerosus.

questions.text: A sexually active 37-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 7-day history of itching in the area of his genitals. He also reports burning on micturition. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, which is well controlled with oral metformin. Pelvic examination shows tender, atrophic white papules on the glans and prepuce, with erythema of the surrounding skin. The urinary meatus is narrowed and sclerotic. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Test lesion with acetic acid application

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Application of acetic acid can be used to identify genital warts because HPV-infected skin or mucosa stains white with acetic acid. Genital warts can appear as papules on the glans but erythema, itching, and dysuria would not be present.

B) INCORRECT:

A superpotent topical corticosteroid such as clobetasol can be used to treat lichen sclerosus. However, a different step is required before therapy can be initiated.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical fluconazole would be used to treat candidiasis. Candidal balanitis would appear as itchy, white lesions on the glans surrounded by erythema; candidal cystitis can result in dysuria. However, atrophy of the epidermis of the glans, and sclerosis of the urethral meatus would not be expected.

D) CORRECT:

Adult patients with lichen sclerosus are at increased risk of developing squamous cell carcinoma. A punch biopsy of the lesion should be performed to rule out dysplastic changes or squamous cell carcinoma. Once neoplastic changes are ruled out, the lesions can be treated with highly potent topical steroids such as clobetasol. Patients who have not been circumcised should be advised to undergo circumcision. If lichen sclerosus causes scarring of the urethral meatus that is severe enough to affect urine outflow, a meatoplasty should be performed.
Image Description:

Irregularly shaped, slightly hard white plaque surrounded by an inflammatory halo on the preputial skin. When retracted, the foreskin appears entrapped and constricts the penile shaft; this is most likely pathologic phimosis.

E) INCORRECT:

A KOH mount of scraping from the glans can be used to diagnose a fungal infection such as candidiasis. Candidal balanitis would appear as itchy, white lesions on the glans surrounded by erythema; candidal cystitis can result in dysuria. However, atrophy of the epidermis of the glans, and sclerosis of the urethral meatus would not be expected.
questions.hint: White, atrophic papules on the glans and prepuce of a male, associated with pruritus and scarring of the urethral meatus are indicative of lichen sclerosus.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician because of vaginal itchiness and urinary frequency for the past year. She stopped having vaginal intercourse with her husband because it became painful and occasionally resulted in vaginal spotting. Her last menstrual period was 14 months ago. She has vitiligo. Her only medication is a topical tacrolimus ointment. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 135/82 mm Hg. Examination shows multiple white maculae on her forearms, abdomen, and feet. Pelvic examination shows scarce pubic hair, vulvar pallor, and narrowing of the vaginal introitus. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's current symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Thinning of the vaginal mucosa leading to tissue inflammation is characteristic of genitourinary syndrome of menopause, which is most commonly caused by decreased estrogen levels after menopause. Signs and symptoms in addition to this patient's urogenital findings include decreased vulvovaginal secretions and sensation of vulvovaginal dryness, loss of vaginal elasticity and rugal folds, a decreased labial fat pad, vaginal discharge, and recurrent urinary tract infections. Genitourinary syndrome of menopause is primarily a clinical diagnosis and treatment consists of nonhormonal vaginal moisturizers and lubricants, as well as topical or systemic estrogen therapy in more severe cases.

B) INCORRECT:

Inflammation of the greater vestibular glands (Bartholin glands) may lead to blockage of the Bartholin duct, fluid buildup, and cystic dilation of the glands. Bartholin gland cysts are most commonly asymptomatic but may manifest with dyspareunia. However, these cysts are not associated with vaginal itchiness, postcoital spotting, urinary frequency, scarce pubic hair, vulvar pallor, or a narrowed vaginal introitus. Moreover, Bartholin gland cysts are typically palpable at the base of the labia minora.

C) INCORRECT:

Atrophic vaginitis is caused by a decrease in estrogen levels, most commonly due to menopause. Estrogen regulates the pH of the lower genital tract by acting on vaginal and cervical epithelial cells to increase acid secretion. Atrophic vaginitis is therefore associated with an increase, not decrease, in vaginal pH (typically ≥ 5; normal vaginal pH 4–4.5).

D) INCORRECT:

This patient's genital symptoms raise concern for vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN) (i.e., epithelial dysplasia), a precancerous lesion that is most commonly seen in postmenopausal women. However, VIN is not typically associated with urinary frequency, scarce pubic hair, or narrowing of the vaginal introitus. Instead, common examination findings include vulvar plaques, ulcers, or masses (fleshy, nodular, or warty), and lymphadenopathy.

E) INCORRECT:

Overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria (e.g., Gardnerella vaginalis) secondary to a decrease in vaginal lactobacilli colonization and a subsequent pH increase is characteristic of bacterial vaginosis (BV). BV may manifest with vaginal itchiness and dyspareunia. However, this infection is not associated with postcoital spotting, urinary frequency, scarce pubic hair, vulvar pallor, and/or narrowed vaginal introitus. Moreover, BV typically manifests with increased gray or milky vaginal discharge with a fishy odor, which is not present in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

This patient's genital symptoms raise concern for lichen sclerosus (LS), a chronic inflammatory condition characterized by sclerosis of the vulvar dermis and most commonly seen in postmenopausal women. However, vulvar LS is not associated with urinary frequency and scarce pubic hair. Instead, common findings include dysuria, anal discomfort, and characteristic porcelain-white atrophic patches as well as obliteration of the labia minora and clitoris on examination. Moreover, the multiple white cutaneous spots found on examination can be attributed to her vitiligo.
Image Description:

An irregular, sclerotic white plaque with a reddened, inflammatory edge localized to the vulva and perianal region is visible. The labia minora and majora are hard to distinguish from one another because of atrophy and sclerosis; the vaginal opening is markedly narrowed.
questions.hint: Scarce pubic hair, vulvar pallor, a narrowed vaginal introitus, and vaginal dryness leading to dyspareunia are consistent with genitourinary syndrome of menopause (atrophic vaginitis).

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician by her mother because of increasing itchiness and burning in the genital area for the past week. The mother says her daughter woke up several times the night before due to the itching. When examining her genital area, she noticed white lesions around the opening of her vagina. The girl has also had constipation for the past few days. She has not had any vaginal discharge. Her older brother has psoriasis. Her immunizations are up-to-date. She appears well. She is at the 75th percentile for height and 40th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the genital area shows erythema and thin, white, well-demarcated plaques on the labia minora, clitoral hood, and perineum. There is a small tear in the anterior midline of the anoderm. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical clotrimazole therapy is indicated in the treatment of vulvovaginal candidiasis, which typically manifests with pruritus and erythema of the vulva and vagina. However, white plaques and anal fissures are not expected in this condition. Moreover, patients with vulvovaginal candidiasis typically have white, crumbly, and sticky vaginal discharge that may appear like cottage cheese, which is not seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

Biopsy specimens are indicated in adult patients with suspected lichen sclerosus if there is doubt in diagnosis and to rule out squamous cell carcinoma, for which there is an increased risk in patients with lichen sclerosus. However, diagnosis is usually clinical in pediatric patients and a biopsy is rarely required; therefore, a biopsy is not the most appropriate next step in management.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral metronidazole therapy is the treatment of choice for bacterial vulvovaginitis (i.e., infection with Gardnerella vaginalis), which is typically asymptomatic and does not manifest with vaginal erythema, discharge, pruritus, and white plaques. Furthermore, bacterial vulvovaginitis is most common in women of childbearing age and in sexually active women. Antibiotic therapy is ineffective for lichen sclerosus.

D) INCORRECT:

Child abuse should always be considered in children with genital symptoms (e.g., injuries in the anogenital area or signs of sexually transmitted infections) and suspected cases must be reported to Child Protective Services. This patient does not present with further findings that raise suspicion for child abuse (e.g., vaginal bleeding, recurrent urinary tract infections or sexually transmitted infections, behavior/sexual insight inconsistent with age).

E) CORRECT:

The initial treatment of anogenital lichen sclerosus in both children and adults consists of patient education on vaginal hygiene and scratching cessation as well as pharmacological treatment with a superpotent topical corticosteroid, such as clobetasol. To prevent long-term sequelae, initial treatment can be followed up with local maintenance therapy (either with topical corticosteroids or topical calcineurin inhibitors). In adults, a punch biopsy of the lesions is recommended before initiating therapy to rule out dysplastic changes or squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). In pediatric patients, the diagnosis is usually clinical. Nonetheless, pediatric patients and their parents should be educated on the association between lichen sclerosus and SCC and advised to regularly examine the anogenital skin for cancerous lesions.
Image Description:

Photographs of two pediatric vulvas

Porcelain-white, polygonal, well-demarcated plaques in a figure-eight appearance involve the vulvar and perianal area. In the left picture, the atrophic patches are surrounded by an inflammatory erythematous halo.

These findings are typical of lichen sclerosus.
questions.hint: This patient's anal fissures, constipation, and severely itchy thin, white plaques in the vulva and perianal region are consistent with anogenital lichen sclerosus.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 4-month history of vulvar itching and dryness. During this period, she has also had pain during sexual intercourse but no postcoital bleeding. Her last menstrual period was at the age of 51 years. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and her only medication is metformin. Pelvic examination shows atrophic labial folds. There are excoriation marks and a well-demarcated, white plaque on the vulva. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The results of a punch biopsy show no evidence of malignancy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment for this patient's lesions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical fluconazole is indicated to treat mucocutaneous fungal infections like candidiasis (vaginal yeast infection). This patient's age puts her at increased risk of secondary infections of the genital area as a complication of atrophic vaginitis. A yeast infection would also explain the vulval pruritus and dyspareunia in this case. However, the absence of key features like vaginal discharge, foul odor, and vulvovaginal inflammation make this diagnosis unlikely.

B) CORRECT:

Individuals with lichen sclerosus have an increased risk of developing vulvar squamous cell carcinoma. Because the results of this patient's biopsy are negative for malignancy, the next step in management is to administer superpotent topical glucocorticoids, such as betamethasone or clobetasol, which help reduce inflammation and pruritus.
Image Description:

An irregular, sclerotic white plaque with a reddened, inflammatory edge localized to the vulva and perianal region is visible. The labia minora and majora are hard to distinguish from one another because of atrophy and sclerosis; the vaginal opening is markedly narrowed.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical tacrolimus (FK506) is a calcineurin inhibitor that can be used to treat lichen sclerosus topically. However, this is a second-line therapy because it is less effective than another therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Although topical progesterone was used in the past for lichen sclerosus, it is no longer used as it is less effective than other forms of therapy and is not approved by the FDA.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical estrogen is the treatment of choice for atrophic vaginitis, which often manifests in postmenopausal women with vulval dryness and dyspareunia in association with labial atrophy. However, this condition does not cause white, plaque-like lesions or pruritus.
questions.hint: Dyspareunia and pruritus in a postmenopausal woman with a white vulvar plaque on pelvic examination are consistent with lichen sclerosus.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 1-year history of vaginal itchiness and urinary frequency. She reports that she stopped having vaginal intercourse with her husband because it became painful and sometimes caused vaginal spotting. Her last menstrual period was 14 months ago. She has a history of vitiligo and uses only topical tacrolimus ointment. Her temperature is 37.1°C, pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 135/82 mm Hg. On examination, there are multiple white maculae on her forearms, abdomen, and feet. Pelvic examination reveals scarce pubic hair, vulvar pallor, and narrowing of the vaginal introitus. Which one of the following is the most likely underlying cause of her current symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Atrophic vaginitis is caused by a decrease in estrogen levels, most commonly due to menopause. Estrogen regulates the pH of the lower genital tract by acting on vaginal and cervical epithelial cells to increase acid secretion. Atrophic vaginitis is therefore associated with an increase, not decrease, in vaginal pH (typically ≥ 5; normal vaginal pH 4–4.5).

B) INCORRECT:

This patient's genital symptoms raise concern for lichen sclerosus (LS), a chronic inflammatory condition characterized by sclerosis of the vulvar dermis and most commonly seen in postmenopausal women. However, vulvar LS is not associated with urinary frequency and scarce pubic hair. Instead, common findings include dysuria, anal discomfort, and characteristic porcelain-white atrophic patches as well as obliteration of the labia minora and clitoris on examination. Moreover, the multiple white cutaneous spots found on examination can be attributed to her vitiligo.

C) INCORRECT:

Overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria (e.g., Gardnerella vaginalis) secondary to a decrease in vaginal lactobacilli colonization and a subsequent pH increase is characteristic of bacterial vaginosis (BV). BV may manifest with vaginal itchiness and dyspareunia. However, this infection is not associated with postcoital spotting, urinary frequency, scarce pubic hair, vulvar pallor, and/or narrowed vaginal introitus. Moreover, BV typically manifests with increased gray or milky vaginal discharge with a fishy odor, which is not present in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Thinning of the vaginal mucosa leading to tissue inflammation is characteristic of genitourinary syndrome of menopause, which is most commonly caused by decreased estrogen levels after menopause. Signs and symptoms in addition to this patient's urogenital findings include decreased vulvovaginal secretions and sensation of vulvovaginal dryness, loss of vaginal elasticity and rugal folds, a decreased labial fat pad, vaginal discharge, and recurrent urinary tract infections. Genitourinary syndrome of menopause is primarily a clinical diagnosis and treatment consists of nonhormonal vaginal moisturizers and lubricants, as well as topical or systemic estrogen therapy in more severe cases.

Key learning point: Genitourinary syndrome of menopause is caused by estrogen deficiency leading to thinning of the vaginal mucosa, resulting in dryness, irritation, dyspareunia, and urinary symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient's genital symptoms raise concern for vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN) (i.e., epithelial dysplasia), a precancerous lesion that is most commonly seen in postmenopausal women. However, VIN is not typically associated with urinary frequency, scarce pubic hair, or narrowing of the vaginal introitus. Instead, common examination findings include vulvar plaques, ulcers, or masses (fleshy, nodular, or warty), and lymphadenopathy.
questions.hint: Scarce pubic hair, vulvar pallor, a narrowed vaginal introitus, and vaginal dryness leading to dyspareunia are consistent with genitourinary syndrome of menopause (atrophic vaginitis).

questions.text: A 37-year-old sexually active man comes to your clinic with a 7-day history of genital itching and burning on urination. On examination, there are tender, atrophic white papules on the glans and prepuce, with surrounding erythema. The urinary meatus appears narrowed and sclerotic. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A KOH mount of scraping from the glans can be used to diagnose a fungal infection such as candidiasis. Candidal balanitis would appear as itchy, white lesions on the glans surrounded by erythema; candidal cystitis can result in dysuria. However, atrophy of the epidermis of the glans, and sclerosis of the urethral meatus would not be expected.

B) INCORRECT:

A superpotent topical corticosteroid such as clobetasol can be used to treat lichen sclerosus. However, a different step is required before therapy can be initiated.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical clotrimazole would be used to treat candidiasis. Candidal balanitis would appear as itchy, white lesions on the glans surrounded by erythema; candidal cystitis can result in dysuria. However, atrophy of the epidermis of the glans and sclerosis of the urethral meatus would not be expected.

D) CORRECT:

Adult patients with lichen sclerosus are at increased risk of developing squamous cell carcinoma. A punch biopsy of the lesion should be performed to rule out dysplastic changes or squamous cell carcinoma. Once neoplastic changes are ruled out, the lesions can be treated with highly potent topical steroids such as clobetasol. Patients who have not been circumcised should be advised to undergo circumcision. If lichen sclerosus causes scarring of the urethral meatus that is severe enough to affect urine outflow, a meatoplasty should be performed.

Key learning point: In adults with suspected lichen sclerosus, a biopsy should be performed to rule out squamous cell carcinoma before starting topical steroid therapy.
Image Description:

Irregularly shaped, slightly hard white plaque surrounded by an inflammatory halo on the preputial skin. When retracted, the foreskin appears entrapped and constricts the penile shaft; this is most likely pathologic phimosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Acetic acid does not have a role in the diagnostic workup of lichen sclerosus and may even cause discomfort when applied to atrophic areas. Application of acetic acid may identify genital warts because HPV-infected skin or mucosa stains white with acetic acid, but this test has a high false-positive rate. Moreover, genital warts can appear as papules on the glans, but erythema, itching, and dysuria would not be present.
questions.hint: White, atrophic papules on the glans and prepuce of a male, associated with pruritus and scarring of the urethral meatus are indicative of lichen sclerosus.
